oops.polymorphism: Polymorphism allows methods to do different things based on the object it is acting upon. It is achieved via method overloading and overriding.
oops.inheritance: Inheritance allows a class (child) to acquire properties and behavior of another class (parent). It promotes code reuse.
oops.encapsulation: Encapsulation is the bundling of data and methods that operate on that data within one unit, like a class. It hides internal state from outside.
oops.abstraction: Abstraction hides unnecessary implementation details and shows only essential features. It’s implemented using abstract classes or interfaces.
oops.class and object: A class is a blueprint, and an object is an instance of that class. Objects hold state and behavior defined by the class.
oops.constructor: A constructor is a special method invoked when an object is created. It initializes object properties.
oops.destructor: A destructor is called when an object is destroyed, used to release resources or perform clean-up.
oops.method overloading: Method overloading allows multiple methods with the same name but different parameters in a class.
oops.method overriding: Method overriding means redefining a method in a derived class that already exists in the base class.
oops.this keyword: The `this` keyword refers to the current object. It's used to access members of the current class.
oops.interface vs abstract class: An interface only defines method signatures without implementation. An abstract class can have both abstract and concrete methods. Interfaces support multiple inheritance; abstract classes do not.
oops.static keyword: The `static` keyword makes a method or variable belong to the class instead of an instance. It can be accessed without creating an object.
oops.access specifiers: Access specifiers like public, private, and protected control the visibility of class members.
oops.object slicing: Object slicing occurs when an object of a derived class is assigned to a base class object, and derived-specific members are 'sliced off'.

dbms.acid properties: ACID stands for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability — properties that ensure reliable transactions.
dbms.normalization: Normalization is the process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity using forms like 1NF, 2NF, 3NF.
dbms.denormalization: Denormalization is the process of introducing redundancy to improve performance by reducing joins.
dbms.sql: SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to manage and query relational databases.
dbms.joins: Joins combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column. Types include INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL JOIN.
dbms.indexing: Indexing improves the speed of data retrieval at the cost of extra storage and slower insertions.
dbms.views: A view is a virtual table based on the result-set of an SQL query. It simplifies complex queries.
dbms.triggers: A trigger is a procedural code that is automatically executed in response to certain events on a table.
dbms.primary key: A primary key uniquely identifies each record in a table. It cannot have NULLs and must be unique.
dbms.foreign key: A foreign key is a field in one table that refers to the primary key in another. It enforces referential integrity.
dbms.transaction: A transaction is a sequence of operations that are treated as a single logical unit of work. It must be ACID compliant.
dbms.concurrency control: Concurrency control ensures correct results for concurrent database transactions by managing simultaneous operations.
dbms.2pl (Two-Phase Locking): 2PL ensures serializability using two phases: growing (acquiring locks) and shrinking (releasing locks).
dbms.er diagram: ER Diagram is a visual representation of entities and their relationships used in database design.
dbms.difference between delete and truncate: `DELETE` removes rows based on a condition and can be rolled back. `TRUNCATE` removes all rows quickly and cannot be rolled back in some databases.

os.process vs thread: A process is an independent program in execution, while a thread is a lightweight unit within a process.
os.scheduling algorithms: These determine the execution order of processes. Examples: FCFS, SJF, Priority, Round Robin.
os.deadlock: A deadlock is a state where a set of processes is blocked because each is waiting for a resource held by the other.
os.memory management: OS handles memory allocation and deallocation using techniques like paging, segmentation, and virtual memory.
os.paging: Paging is a memory management technique where processes are divided into fixed-size pages and stored in frames.
os.segmentation: Segmentation divides memory into variable-sized segments based on logical divisions like functions or arrays.
os.file system: The file system manages how data is stored and retrieved. It organizes files into directories and manages permissions.
os.system calls: System calls are the interface between the OS and user programs to request OS services like I/O, memory, or file handling.
os.interrupts: Interrupts are signals to the processor indicating an event that needs immediate attention.
os.virtual memory: Virtual memory uses hardware and software to allow the execution of processes that may not be fully in physical memory.
os.mutex vs semaphore: A mutex allows only one thread to access a resource at a time. A semaphore is a counter used to manage access to multiple instances of a resource.
os.context switching: Context switching is the process of saving and loading the state of a CPU so that execution can resume from the same point later.
os.thrashing: Thrashing happens when the OS spends more time swapping pages in and out of memory than executing actual processes.
os.multithreading: Multithreading is the ability of a CPU to execute multiple threads concurrently, improving performance and resource utilization.
os.kernel and user mode: Kernel mode allows unrestricted access to system resources, while user mode has restricted access to ensure safety and security.

cn.osi model: The OSI model is a 7-layer conceptual framework used to standardize network functions from physical transmission to application support.
cn.tcp/ip model: A 4-layer model used in real-world networking: Application, Transport, Internet, and Network Access.
cn.ip address: An IP address is a unique identifier assigned to each device connected to a network using the Internet Protocol.
cn.subnetting: Subnetting divides a network into smaller, efficient sub-networks, improving performance and security.
cn.dns: Domain Name System translates human-readable domain names (like google.com) into IP addresses.
cn.mac address: MAC address is a hardware address that uniquely identifies each device on a local network.
cn.switch vs router: A switch connects devices in the same network; a router connects different networks and manages traffic between them.
cn.http vs https: HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP, where data is encrypted using SSL/TLS for secure communication.
cn.firewall: A firewall monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on security rules.
cn.packet switching: Packet switching breaks data into packets sent independently across the network. It's the basis of internet communication.
cn.udp vs tcp: TCP is connection-oriented, reliable, and slower; UDP is connectionless, faster, but unreliable. TCP is used in HTTP, while UDP is used in streaming.
cn.congestion control: Congestion control techniques (e.g., slow start, congestion avoidance) ensure efficient network utilization by preventing overload.
cn.ssl/tls: SSL/TLS are cryptographic protocols that provide encrypted communication and authentication over a network.
cn.icmp: ICMP is used for error reporting and diagnostics in networks, such as with the `ping` and `traceroute` tools.
cn.arp protocol: Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) maps an IP address to a MAC address in a local network.
